score_reasons.low_protein_advice: Protein is essential for hormone balance, muscle maintenance, and satiety. Aim for 20-30g per meal. Good sources: eggs, fish, legumes, nuts, dairy, meat.
score_reasons.low_fiber_advice: Fiber supports your gut, hormone elimination, and blood sugar regulation. Add extra vegetables, legumes, oatmeal, or chia seeds. Aim for 25-30g per day.
score_reasons.high_ultra_processed_advice: Ultra-processed foods can increase inflammation and destabilize blood sugar. Choose unprocessed alternatives with recognizable ingredients where possible.
score_reasons.few_meals_advice: Eating regularly (3-4x per day) keeps blood sugar stable and prevents energy dips. Skipping meals can increase cortisol.
score_reasons.no_breakfast_advice: A protein-rich breakfast within 1-2 hours of waking helps regulate stress hormones and provides a stable start to the day.
score_reasons.late_eating_advice: Eating close to bedtime can affect sleep quality. Try to finish your last meal 2-3 hours before bed.
score_reasons.skipped_meal_advice: Skipping meals can activate your stress system, especially in the luteal phase. Try to eat regularly, even if you're not very hungry.
score_reasons.good_protein_advice: Great! Adequate protein supports your muscles, hormones, and satiety. Keep it up.
score_reasons.good_fiber_advice: Excellent! Your fiber intake looks good. This helps your gut and hormone balance.
score_reasons.balanced_meals_advice: Excellent! Your meals are well-composed with a good balance of macronutrients.

sleep.hygiene_1: Keep a consistent sleep schedule, even on weekends
sleep.hygiene_2: Avoid screens 1 hour before bed (blue light inhibits melatonin)
sleep.hygiene_4: Avoid caffeine after 2pm and alcohol close to bedtime
sleep.hygiene_5: Make your bedroom as dark as possible
sleep.hygiene_6: Exercise regularly, but not right before bed

nutrition: Warm meals support your digestion and provide comfort. Think stews, soups, and casseroles.
Keep blood sugar stable with regular protein-rich meals. Avoid long periods without eating.
Eat a variety of vegetables for nutrients.
Reduce caffeine and alcohol for better sleep.
training: Take it easy. Your body is recovering and rebuilding.
Ideal for: walking, gentle yoga, stretching, mobility, and breathwork.
Avoid high intensity training the first 2-3 days if you're bleeding heavily.
Really listen to your body - if you're tired, rest.
Technique training without intensity is fine: focus on form, not weight.
work: Ideal time for reflection, evaluation, and strategic thinking.
Schedule fewer meetings and social commitments where possible.
Finishing ongoing tasks fits better than starting new projects.
Admin, planning, and quiet desk work feel more natural now.
Set boundaries: this is not the time to say yes to everything.
recovery: Prioritize sleep: go to bed earlier and wake up later if possible.
Heat helps: hot water bottle, warm shower, warm drinks.
Say no to non-essential social commitments.
This is the time for solo activities: reading, journaling, rest.

nutrition: Your insulin sensitivity is optimal now - your body processes carbs efficiently.
Lots of fresh vegetables and fruit, your appetite may be lower than in other phases.
Adequate protein for muscle building (1.6-2g per kg body weight when training).
Carbs around training optimize performance and recovery.
Experiment with new recipes and ingredients - you're more open to it now.
training: This is the phase to build! Your body responds optimally to training load.
Strength training with progressive overload fits excellently.
HIIT and intervals if you feel good - energy levels are often higher.
Try new workouts or challenges you've been putting off.
You recover faster, so you can train more frequently.
work: Creativity and new thinking peak in this phase.
Start new projects, brainstorm, plan the coming month.
Presentations, pitches, and creative sessions often go easier now.
You're more communicative and open - schedule important conversations.
Learning and picking up new skills goes smoother.
recovery: You often have more energy for social activities.
Despite higher energy: keep prioritizing sleep (7-9 hours).
Active recovery works well: light movement, swimming, cycling.
You can handle more, but beware of overcommitment.
This is a good time for preventive self-care: massage, sauna.

nutrition: Light but nutritious food often feels best. Large meals can feel heavy.
Extra attention to hydration - drink enough water and add electrolytes during intense training.
Enough salt in your diet, especially if you sweat a lot.
Fresh salads, grilled vegetables, and lean protein fit well.
Your appetite may fluctuate - listen to your hunger signals.
training: This is your peak! You can perform at your highest level.
PR attempts, competitions, and tests fit best in this phase.
You can handle more intense sessions - as long as recovery is in order.
Competitive elements and challenges feel motivating.
Note: this drops quickly after ovulation, plan your peak performances consciously.
work: Negotiating, pitching, and persuading come easier to you.
You're at your most communicative and radiate more confidence.
Schedule important meetings, presentations, and job interviews.
Networking and making new contacts feels more natural.
Leadership tasks and visibility fit this phase.
recovery: Social activities feel less tiring.
Your libido may be higher - this is biologically intended.
Enjoy social contacts, but beware of overstimulation.
You may feel superhuman - but rest remains important.
Mentally prepare for the phase ahead: the energy dip after ovulation.

nutrition: Stable meal frequency is crucial - don't skip meals.
Start each day with protein: this stabilizes blood sugar and mood.
Reduce ultra-processed foods, sugar, and alcohol - these can worsen symptoms.
Nutritious foods (nuts, seeds, dark chocolate, leafy greens) help.
Complex carbs (sweet potato, quinoa) support your energy.
training: Maintaining strength is the goal, not necessarily chasing PRs.
Less high intensity if you're irritable or tired.
Steady-state cardio and moderate strength training often work better.
Listen to your body - sometimes rest is better than pushing through.
Yoga and pilates can help with tension and restlessness.
The week before your period: consider reducing intensity.
work: Structuring, organizing, and finishing fits better than starting.
Plan deadlines wisely - preferably not right before your period.
Detail-oriented work can go well - you're more critical.
Start fewer new big projects.
Be kind to yourself when concentration is harder.
Solo work can feel more productive than team projects.
recovery: Sleep becomes extra important - you often need more.
Stress has more impact now - active stress regulation is essential.
Breathing, meditation, and rest prevent tension from building up.
Social energy may be lower - consciously plan less.
Warm baths and early to bed help with recovery.
This is prevention: what you do now determines how you feel.

nutrition: Focus on varied, nutritious eating with enough protein and fiber.
Eat regularly to keep blood sugar stable.
Drink enough water throughout the day.
training: Move in a way that feels good. Listen to your body.
Vary between intense and restful days.
Rest is also training.
work: Plan your tasks flexibly.
Be kind to yourself on low-energy days.
recovery: Make sure to get enough rest and relaxation.
Prioritize sleep and stress management.

what_is.title: What is perimenopause?
what_is.paragraph_1: Perimenopause is the transitional period leading up to menopause. This phase can begin in women around their 30s, but typically starts between ages 40 and 45. Perimenopause can last 4 to 10 years.
what_is.paragraph_2: During perimenopause, your hormone levels begin to fluctuate. Especially estrogen and progesterone fluctuate significantly, leading to various physical and mental changes.
what_is.paragraph_3: These hormonal fluctuations can lead to irregular periods, hot flashes, sleep problems, mood swings, weight gain, and concentration issues. The good news: with the right insights, you can better understand and manage many of these symptoms.
what_is.chart_note: Notice the significant fluctuations - this explains why symptoms can vary

symptoms.title: Perimenopause symptoms in numbers
symptoms.description: 80-90% of women experience symptoms during perimenopause. For some women, the first symptoms start around their 30s. These are the most common symptoms:
symptoms.disclaimer: * Percentages are based on averages from scientific research. Individual experiences may vary significantly.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.description: Everything you want to know about perimenopause and our app

q1.question: What is perimenopause?
q1.answer: Perimenopause is the transitional period to menopause, which typically begins between your 40s and 50s. During this phase, your hormones fluctuate, which can lead to symptoms such as irregular periods, hot flashes, sleep problems, and mood swings. This period can last 4 to 10 years.

q2.question: What is cycle syncing?
q2.answer: Cycle syncing means adjusting your nutrition, exercise, and activities to your cycle phase. Each phase (menstruation, follicular phase, ovulation, and luteal phase) has different hormonal characteristics. By taking this into account, you can perform better, have fewer symptoms, and optimize your energy levels. Our app gives you daily advice based on your cycle phase.

q3.question: How can I predict my period?
q3.answer: With Perimenopause Plan, you can easily predict your period online. Log your cycle data and the app automatically predicts your next period. Our smart calculator accounts for irregular cycles typical during perimenopause, so you still get a reliable prediction.

q4.question: Who is this app for?
q4.answer: This app is specifically designed for women in perimenopause - the transitional period that typically begins between your 40s and 50s. Women who suspect they are entering this phase, or who want to track their cycle and gain more insight into the relationship between their hormones, nutrition, and wellbeing can also benefit from the app.

q5.question: How does the AI analysis work?
q5.answer: Our AI analyzes your entered data - meals, sleep, symptoms, and cycle data - to discover patterns. You receive personalized insights about how your nutrition and lifestyle affect your symptoms. The AI provides suggestions tailored to your specific situation and cycle phase.

q6.question: Is my data safe?
q6.answer: Absolutely. We take privacy very seriously. All data is encrypted and processed according to GDPR guidelines. Your health data is never shared with third parties or used for advertising. You always have full control over your own data and can delete it at any time.

q7.question: How much does the app cost?
q7.answer: You can try the app free for 7 days without a credit card. After that, the Basic subscription costs ‚Ç¨7.50 per month, which gives you access to all tracking features. The Premium subscription for ‚Ç¨14 per month includes additional AI analyses and personalized coaching.

q8.question: Can I try the app for free?
q8.answer: Yes! You get 7 days of free access to all Premium features. This way you can extensively test whether the app suits you. After the trial period, you decide whether to continue with a paid subscription.

q9.question: Does the app provide medical advice?
q9.answer: No, Perimenopause Plan is a wellness app and does not provide medical advice. The app helps you discover patterns and offers general information, but does not replace a doctor or specialist. For medical complaints, we always recommend contacting a healthcare provider.

intended_use.title: Intended Use Statement
intended_use.subtitle: Perimenopause Plan
intended_use.intended_use_p1: This app is intended to give users insight into lifestyle and cycle-related patterns, such as nutrition, wellbeing, and experienced symptoms.
intended_use.intended_use_p2: The app supports self-observation and awareness and focuses on prevention and lifestyle.
intended_use.intended_use_p3: The app does not make medical diagnoses, prognoses, or provide support for medical treatments or therapy choices.
intended_use.intended_use_p4: The information and insights provided by the app are not intended to replace professional medical advice.
intended_use.mdr_p1: Perimenopause Plan is NOT a medical device within the meaning of the EU Medical Devices Regulation (MDR 2017/745).
intended_use.mdr_p2: The software falls outside the scope of the MDR because it has no medical purpose and is not intended for diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, prediction, prognosis, treatment, or alleviation of disease.
intended_use.product_description: Perimenopause Plan is a mobile/web application for lifestyle support and self-observation, specifically designed for women in perimenopause. The app enables users to track personal data and recognize patterns to support their overall wellbeing.
intended_use.purpose_self_observation_desc: Tracking menstrual cycle, symptoms, mood, and energy levels
intended_use.purpose_patterns_desc: Visualization of trends in your own data
intended_use.purpose_conversation_desc: Data export for discussions with healthcare providers
intended_use.contra_intro: The app is NOT intended for:
intended_use.contra_treatment: Prescribing or advising treatments or medication
intended_use.contra_clinical: Supporting clinical decision-making by healthcare providers
intended_use.target_primary_desc: Women in perimenopause who want to support their lifestyle and wellbeing through self-observation and conscious choices.
intended_use.target_context_desc: Personal/home use, not in clinical settings
intended_use.safeguards_intro: The following measures are implemented to ensure non-medical use:
intended_use.safeguards_1: AI guardrails that block medical claims, diagnoses, and treatment advice
intended_use.safeguards_3: Consent flow with medical disclaimer before first use
intended_use.safeguards_4: No connection to medical equipment or care systems
intended_use.safeguards_5: No claims about effectiveness for conditions
intended_use.regulatory_1: EU Regulation 2017/745 (MDR) - Article 2, definition of medical device
intended_use.regulatory_2: MDCG 2019-11 Guidance on Qualification and Classification of Software
intended_use.regulatory_3: MDCG 2021-24 Guidance on classification of medical devices
intended_use.regulatory_conclusion: The app does not meet the MDR definition of a medical device because its primary purpose is lifestyle support and education, not diagnosis, treatment, or monitoring of disease.
intended_use.warning_text: If you have medical complaints or are concerned about your health, always contact a qualified healthcare provider. The information in this app is not a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.
intended_use.document_info: This document serves as formal documentation of the intended use of Perimenopause Plan in accordance with EU regulations.

default.quote: Focus on rhythm and balance in this phase.
feelings: Your energy may be stable, but keep paying attention to signals.
Listen to your body and give it what it needs.
focus: Maintain your rhythm with regular meals.

winter.quote: Rest and recovery are central in your winter phase.
feelings: Your energy may be a bit lower - that's normal.
More need for warmth and comfort.
focus: Warm, nutritious meals support your body.

lente.quote: Your energy is building up - enjoy this upward phase!
focus: This is a good time to start projects.
Your body responds well to training.

planningTips.details: Your concentration is at its best now

zomer.quote: This is your peak moment - use your energy wisely!
focus: Enjoy, but watch out for overcommitment.

herfst.quote: Time for structure and self-care in your autumn phase.
feelings: More need for rhythm and rest.
focus: Stable blood sugar helps with mood swings.

herfst-winter.quote: The coming days: less pushing, more protecting.
feelings: More need for rest and comfort food, especially late afternoon.
Sleep may be lighter and you might wake up more easily.
You may feel less stress-resistant, small things hit harder.
focus: Keep blood sugar stable with regular meals and protein at breakfast.
Protect sleep with earlier dinner and fewer stimuli late in the day.

eatingTips.action: Breakfast with 25 to 35 grams of protein
Last real meal at least 3 hours before sleep

planningTips.details: Goal: earlier to bed, screens off 45 minutes before sleep
2x strength or brisk walking, 1x yoga or gentle flow. No max intensity.

winter-lente.quote: The coming days: build up slowly, your energy is returning.
feelings: More desire for plans and movement.
focus: Slowly build up activities, don't go full throttle right away.
Varied eating supports your energy recovery.

eatingTips.action: Keep protein intake high, especially at breakfast

planningTips.details: Your concentration is better in this phase
Your muscles can handle more now

lente-zomer.quote: The coming days: enjoy your peak energy!
feelings: More drive, more desire for action.
focus: Use your energy for important tasks and conversations.
Plan recovery too, otherwise it will backfire later.

eatingTips.action: Protein and fiber remain the foundation

planningTips.action: Max 1-2 busy evenings in a row

zomer-herfst.quote: The coming days: back to rhythm and protection.
focus: Earlier evenings and stable meal times.

pricing.title: Perimenopause Plan
pricing.subtitle: AI insights tailored to your cycle, symptoms and lifestyle. Try 7 days free.
pricing.ai_disclaimer: * There is a fair-use limit on AI analyses to prevent misuse.

trial.name: Free Trial
trial.description: Try all basic features for 7 days free.

premium.name: Premium
premium.description: For women in perimenopause who want personal insights.

perimenopause_test.title: Perimenopause Self-Test
perimenopause_test.description: Discover if your symptoms could be related to hormonal changes
perimenopause_test.login_required_desc: You need to be logged in to take the perimenopause test.
perimenopause_test.disclaimer: This test is designed to give you insight into symptoms that could be related to hormonal changes during perimenopause. It is not a medical diagnosis and does not replace a doctor or healthcare provider.
perimenopause_test.expect_3: Personal score with explanation per domain
perimenopause_test.expect_4: You can review or delete your results later
perimenopause_test.consent_label: I consent to processing my answers for personal insights within the app.
perimenopause_test.result_disclaimer: This test does not provide a medical diagnosis. If symptoms persist or worsen, it's wise to discuss this with a doctor or healthcare provider.
perimenopause_test.delete_confirm_desc: Are you sure you want to delete this result? This cannot be undone.

questions_list.cycle_1: My cycle has become more irregular
questions_list.cycle_2: My period is heavier or lighter than before
questions_list.cycle_4: I have hot flashes or heat waves
questions_list.energy_1: I often feel tired despite enough sleep
questions_list.energy_2: I wake up at night and have trouble falling back asleep
questions_list.energy_3: I don't feel rested in the morning
questions_list.energy_4: My energy fluctuates strongly throughout the day
questions_list.mental_1: I experience more irritability or mood swings
questions_list.mental_2: I have more brain fog or concentration problems
questions_list.mental_3: I feel overwhelmed or stressed more easily
questions_list.mental_4: I don't recognize myself emotionally as well
questions_list.body_1: I gain weight more easily than before
questions_list.body_3: I have more joint or muscle pain
questions_list.body_4: My skin or hair has visibly changed

low.title: Few signals
low.description: Based on your answers, there are currently few indications of symptoms that fit perimenopause. Keep following your body, especially if symptoms change.

moderate.title: Mild to moderate signals
moderate.description: Your answers show that you are experiencing symptoms that could be related to hormonal changes. Many women experience this in the phase before menopause.

high.title: Clear signals
high.description: Your symptom pattern could fit perimenopause. This doesn't mean something is 'wrong', but it does mean your body may respond differently than you're used to.

monthly_analysis.title: Monthly Analysis
monthly_analysis.subtitle: A comprehensive analysis of all your data with orthomolecular insights
monthly_analysis.contains_1: Patterns in sleep, nutrition, mood, and energy
monthly_analysis.once_per_month: You can generate this analysis once per month. All data is processed anonymously.
monthly_analysis.ai_consent_desc: To generate this analysis, consent for AI processing is required. Go to Settings > Privacy to adjust this.
monthly_analysis.we_analyze_30_days: We analyze your data from the last 30 days
monthly_analysis.next_month_available: You can create a new analysis next month

menstrual.name: Menstruation
menstrual.description: Rest and recovery are central. Gentle, restorative exercises that help you relax.

follicular.name: Follicular phase
follicular.description: Your energy is growing! Time for dynamic exercises that build strength and flexibility.

ovulatory.name: Ovulation
ovulatory.description: Peak energy and strength. Challenging exercises that push your limits.

luteal.name: Luteal phase
luteal.description: Time to slow down. Focus on stretching, breathing, and stress relief.

sleep_advice.start_tracking: Start tracking your sleep to get personal advice.
sleep_advice.avg_within_range: Great job! You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours, which falls within the optimal range.
sleep_advice.avg_too_low: You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours. Aim for 7-9 hours for optimal recovery, hormone balance, and mood.
sleep_advice.avg_too_high: You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours. Excessive sleep may indicate underlying fatigue or sleep quality issues.
sleep_advice.consistency_low: Your sleep times vary a lot. Try going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends.
sleep_advice.consistency_high: You have a consistent sleep rhythm. This supports your circadian rhythm and hormone balance.
sleep_advice.quality_low: Your sleep quality could be better. Consider: no screens 1 hour before bed, cool bedroom (60-65¬∞F / 16-18¬∞C), dark room.
sleep_advice.bedtime_late: You often go to bed after midnight. This can disrupt your melatonin production. Try to be in bed before 11pm.
sleep_advice.bedtime_early: You go to bed quite early. If you have trouble staying asleep, try going to bed a bit later.
sleep_advice.general_tip: Avoid caffeine after 2pm and alcohol close to bedtime - both disrupt your sleep architecture.

sleep_advice.no_data: Start tracking your sleep to get personalized advice.
sleep_advice.duration_short: You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours. Aim for 7-9 hours for optimal recovery, hormone balance and mood.
sleep_advice.duration_long: You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours. Excessive sleep may indicate underlying fatigue or sleep quality issues.
sleep_advice.duration_good: Well done! You sleep an average of {{hours}} hours, which is within the optimal range.
sleep_advice.consistency_low: Your sleep times vary a lot. Try going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends.
sleep_advice.consistency_high: You have a consistent sleep rhythm. This supports your circadian rhythm and hormone balance.
sleep_advice.quality_low: Your sleep quality could be better. Consider: no screens 1 hour before bed, cool bedroom (60-65¬∞F / 16-18¬∞C), dark room.
sleep_advice.bedtime_late: You often go to sleep after midnight. This can disrupt your melatonin production. Try to be in bed before 11pm.
sleep_advice.bedtime_early: You go to sleep quite early. If you have trouble staying asleep, try going to bed a bit later.
sleep_advice.general_tip: Avoid caffeine after 2pm and alcohol close to bedtime - both disrupt your sleep architecture.

phase_descriptions.menstrual: Rest and recovery are central. Gentle, restorative exercises to help you relax.
phase_descriptions.follicular: Your energy is growing! Time for dynamic exercises that build strength and flexibility.
phase_descriptions.ovulatory: Peak of energy and strength. Challenging exercises that push your limits.
phase_descriptions.luteal: Time to slow down. Focus on stretching, breathing, and stress relief.

child-pose.name: Child's Pose
child-pose.description: Kneel on the floor, bring your toes together and spread your knees. Bend forward and stretch your arms in front of you or along your body.

supine-twist.name: Supine Twist
supine-twist.description: Lie on your back, pull one knee to your chest and let it fall to the opposite side. Look in the other direction.

legs-up-wall.name: Legs Up the Wall
legs-up-wall.description: Lie on your back with your legs vertically against a wall. Relax completely.

cat-cow.name: Cat-Cow Stretch
cat-cow.description: On hands and knees, alternate between a hollow back (cow) and a rounded back (cat) with your breath.

sun-salutation.name: Sun Salutation
sun-salutation.description: A dynamic series of poses that activates the whole body. Start slowly and build up.

warrior-2.name: Warrior II
warrior-2.description: Stand with legs wide, turn one foot 90 degrees and bend that knee. Stretch your arms to the sides.

triangle-pose.name: Triangle Pose
triangle-pose.description: From a wide stance, bend sideways toward one foot while your arms form a vertical line.

boat-pose.name: Boat Pose
boat-pose.description: Sit with bent knees, lift your feet off the ground and balance on your sit bones with arms extended.

crow-pose.name: Crow Pose
crow-pose.description: Balance on your hands with your knees resting on your upper arms. A challenging arm balance.

headstand-prep.name: Headstand Prep
headstand-prep.description: Dolphin pose with forehead on the floor. Build strength for headstand.

wheel-pose.name: Wheel Pose
wheel-pose.description: Deep backbend with hands and feet on the floor, body arched upward.

dancer-pose.name: Dancer's Pose
dancer-pose.description: Stand on one leg, grab the other ankle and stretch backward while bending forward.

pigeon-pose.name: Pigeon Pose
pigeon-pose.description: From plank, bring one knee forward and extend the other leg back. Bend forward.

seated-forward-fold.name: Seated Forward Fold
seated-forward-fold.description: Sit with legs extended and bend forward from your hips toward your feet.

supported-bridge.name: Supported Bridge
supported-bridge.description: Lie on your back, feet flat on the floor, lift your hips and place a block underneath.

reclined-butterfly.name: Reclined Butterfly
reclined-butterfly.description: Lie on your back, bring the soles of your feet together and let your knees fall to the sides.
